After setting the breakpoint, if I execute code that will cause the breakpoint 
to happen, the application locks up, the breakpoint is never reached, the debug 
perspective does not open and I need to manually kill the application. 

I am running with Sun's JDK 1.4.1_07. I started seeing these exceptions with 
the M8 build and hoped that 3.0 GA would clean up the problems. Unfortunately 
not.

There's a newer JDK from Sun - 1.4.2. Please try the newer JDK to see if it 
fixes the problem.

Also, what is your Java debugger communication timeout value set to (Window > 
Prefences > Java > Debug)?

Unfortunately, our product calls for JDK 1.4.1. I will give 1.4.2 a try but 
I'm afraid there may be conflicts. In fact, when I am running/debugging my 
application, the JRE we are pointing to is actually part of the application 
libraries. 

My debug timeout is set to 10000 ms. Do you recommend a higher setting?

Now this used to work and other folks on my team can debug using JDK 1.4.1. So 
I am not sure what has changed in the last couple of weeks, possibly our 
application. I will upgrade to 1.4.2 and let you know how I make out. 

Thanks,
Moe Kraft

10000 ms should be plenty for local debugging. Do you have a firewall that 
might be causing trouble?

I installed 1.4.2 version of Sun's JDK and I am now able to debug. I launch 
eclipse targetting this JDK although our application is still targetting 
1.4.1. It's a bit slow but I am able to add a breakpoint and step through the 
debugger. 

P.S. I was able to debug the sample "Hello World" plugin using the 1.4.1 JRE. 
I think there is something with our application requiring a specialized 
version of the 1.4.1 JRE that is causing issues. Anyway moving to 1.4.2 seems 
to have helped. 

Thanks,

Marking as won't fix, as we do not intend to modify the debugger to work with 
1.4.1.
